questions.text: A patient was taking steroids as treatment of plaque psoriasis and the medicine was abruptly withdrawn. He now presents with pustules on lesion, as shown in the image. What will be diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Pustular psoriasis triggers by steroid withdrawal.

Generalized:

  • Von-Zumbush type
  • Annular type
  • Pregnancy induced (Impetigo herpetiformis)

Localized

  • Localized pustular psoriasis of palms and soles
  • Acrodermatitis continua of hallopeu

Von Zumbusch type: Severe and acute form of psoriasis which starts with pustules which merge to form "lakes of pus" or "sheets of pus".

Impetigo herpetiformis is Von zumbusch in pregnancy. Systemic steroids are DOC for impetigo herpetiformis.

Treatment of Pustular psoriasis:

Acitretin, Cyclosporine, Methotrexate.

Biologics (TNF- alpha inhibitors)

Option B: Erythrodermic Psoriasis: greater-than90% body surface area shows redness/inflammation or scaling.

Option C: Impetigo is a bacterial Infection caused by gram positive bacteria like streptococci or staphylococci. Common in the pediatric age group.

Option D: Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis is drug reaction characterized by an acute onset of mainly small non-follicular pustules on an erythematous base.

Key Takeaway:

Pustular Psoriasis occurs due to abrupt stoppage of Steroids. It Present with pustules which merge to form lakes of pus.

questions.text: What is not a histological feature of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Max Joseph space is a histology feature of lichen planus not psoriasis.

Histology of psoriasis:

  • Hyperkeratosis
  • Focal parakeratosis ( Option C )
  • Focal hypogranulosis
  • Irregular acanthosis with supra papillary thinning of stratum malpighii
  • Elongation of rete ridges ( Option D )
  • Accumulation of PMNL in stratum corneum, called Munro's microabscess ( Option B )
  • Accumulation of PMNL in stratum granulosum, called Kogoj's pustules
  • Irregular dilated tortuous blood vessels in dermal papilla

Max joseph space:

Basal cell degeneration causes clefts in the dermoepidermal junction called Max joseph space. Seen in Lichen planus. ( Option B )

Key Takeaway :

Psoriasis Histology :

  • Hyperkeratosis with Parakeratosis
  • Munro Microabscess in Stratum corneum
  • Kogoj Pustule in Stratum Granulosum

questions.text: Which characteristic nail finding of Psoriasis vulgaris is being shown in the image
questions.solution:
The above image shows subungual hyperkeratosis

In subungual hyperkeratosis, there is excessive proliferation of nail bed, seen in psoriasis and onychomycosis.

Other changes seen in psoriasis are nail pitting, oil drop sign, onycholysis. ( Option B & D )

Auspitz sign is seen in psoriasis where removal of scales lead to pinpoint bleeding. ( Option A )

Option B: Oil Drop sign -


Key Takeaway:

Nail Psoriasis Mnemonic - POISON

P-Pitting ( Coarse Irregular )

Oi- Oil drop sign

S- Subungual hyperkeratosis

O- Onycholysis

N- Nail dystrophy

questions.text:
Match the following therapeutics used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects.
Column A
1. Methotrexate
2. Cyclosporine
3. PUVA
4. Acitretin
Column B
a. Long term use increases the risk of skin cancer
b. Hepatotoxic
c. Mucositis, Teratogenic
d. Nephrotoxic
questions.solution:
Methotrexate: Hepatotoxic, Bone marrow suppression, Nausea

Cyclosporine: Nephrotoxic, Hypertension

Acitretin: Dyslipidemia, Liver dysfunction, cheilitis, teratogenic

PUVA: Phototoxic erythema(Acute), Long term exposure increases risk for non-melanoma skin cancer

Key Takeaway :

questions.text: A 34 year male patient presented with silvery white scaling over elbow and knees. There was a history of winter aggravation in skin lesions. All of the following nail changes can be seen in this patient, except:
questions.solution:
Mees' Lines are a change that occurs in the color of the nail with no palpable ridges, typically described as white bands traversing the nail bed, running parallel to the lunula across the entire nail bed of the individual. This finding is indicative of arsenic, thallium or other heavy metal poisonings. (Option C)

Nail Psoriasis Clinical signs:

1.Nail Bed Involvement:

Oil-drop sign and salmon patch(Pathognomonic of nail psoriasis) (Option D)

onycholysis - typically with a pink zone proximally

Subungual hyperkeratosis ( Option A )

splinter hemorrhages under the distal third of the nail plate

2.Nail matrix involvement: Pitting (Most Common manifestation) ( Option B )leukonychia

  • Red spots in lunule
  • Onychorrhexis (longitudinal nail ridge, split, or fissure)
  • Beau lines (transverse lines and ridges)
  • Nail crumbling

Nail Psoriasis Severity Index (NAPSI) is a scoring tool for nail psoriasis.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 40 year old patient with chronic plaque psoriasis with 50% BSA involvement. He has no systemic features and no arthritis. Which of the following should not be used in the management?
questions.solution:
Psoriasis management:

  • Topical therapy: (less-than10%)

Topical steroids

Vitamin D3 analogues

Coal tar

Anthralin

Salicylic acid

  • Systemic therapy (greater-than10%) :

Methotrexate ( Option D )

Cyclosporine ( Option C )

Acitretin

  • Phototherapy(greater-than 10%). ( Option A )

Phototherapy of choice- NBUVB (Narrow band UVB) 311mm

PUVA (Psoralen UVA)

PUVA

  • Biologics

Anti TNF (Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab, Certolizumab pegol)

Anti IL-17 ( Secukinumab, Ixekizumab, Brodalumab)

Anti IL12/23 p40 (Ustekinumab)

IL-23 (Guselkumab, Risankizumab)


Steroids are not given in psoriasis.

Exception: Steroids are DOC for impetigo herpetiformis

Key Takeaway:

Steroids are not given in psoriasis.

Exception: Steroids are DOC for impetigo herpetiformis

questions.text: A patient presented with itchy lesions on the body. On examination, oral cavity also had some findings, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
LP may be associated with mucosal (oral and genital) lesions.

Oral mucosa:

Involved in 50% of patients with cutaneous LP and may be the sole manifestation of LP in 10% of patients.

May be asymptomatic. Or patients may complain of intolerance to spicy food.

Different patterns recognized:

  1. White, reticulate lacey pattern (pathognomonic) on the buccal mucosa tongue and gingiva.
  2. White plaques in the buccal mucosa.
  3. Erosive lesions on tongue and buccal mucosa; also erosive gingivitis

Option A: Psoriasis does not involve oral mucosa.

Option C: Oral candidiasis is a fungal infection of the mouth often called 'thrush' because its white spots resemble the breast of the bird with the same name. Candida pseudomembranes are sometimes described as "curdled milk" or "cottage cheese".


Option D: Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disease with oral erosion usually associated with cutaneous vesiculobullous lesions.


Key takeaway:

Lichen Planus involves oral mucosa in white Lacey reticulate pattern.

questions.text: Which of the histopathological findings is not seen in lichen planus?
questions.solution:
Camel foot rete ridges seen in psoriasis hence incorrect option.

Histopathological findings of Lichen planus:

  • Mild hyperkeratosis
  • Irregular acanthosis
  • Focal wedge shaped hypergranulosis (Responsible for Wickham’s striae) ( Option D )
  • Basal cell degeneration. Sometimes lead to clefts in dermoepidermal junction called Max joseph spaces ( Option C )
  • Saw tooth rete ridges
  • Colloid bodies/ civatte/apoptotic bodies in lower epidermis and upper dermis
  • Dense band like mononuclear infiltration at dermoepidermal junction
  • Interface dermatitis ( Option B )
  • Pigment incontinence, presence of melanophages

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 24-year old female presented with pruritic violaceous papules over the flexor aspect of the forearm. Nail findings of this patient were as shown in image. What is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The case given here is LIchen planus.

Lichen planus presents with 5 P's

  • Purple
  • Polygonal
  • Pruritic
  • Plane topped (Flat)
  • Papule

Lesions have flexural predisposition

Nail change shown in the image is nail pterygium (dorsal pterygium) Most classical nail finding

Other changes:

  • Thinning of nail plate is most common nail finding in Lichen planus
  • Pterygium is most classical nail finding. Proximal nail fold fuses with proximal portion of nail bed.
  • Twenty nail dystrophy also called trachyonychia
  • Longitudinal ridging
  • Pup tent sign- Elevation of nail plate in a tent like manner

Option A: Nail Pitting & Cracking is seen in Eczema.

Option B: Psoriasis Nail changes:

  • Oil drop/ Salmon patch: A translucent, yellow discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil beneath the nail plate. (Pathognomonic of nail psoriasis)
  • Nail pitting: MC manifestation. Pitting occur due to involvement of nail matrix
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis: Accumulation of excessive keratin on nail bed.
  • Onycholysis: Separation of nail plate from nail bed.

Option c: Pityriasis rosea causes nail Dystrophy rarely.

Key Takeaway:

Lichen Planus Nail Changes:

  • Pterygium ( Most Specific)
  • Thinning of nail plate
  • Trachyonychia
  • Pup tent sign

questions.text: A 10-year old female presented with itchy violaceous papules over bilateral upper and lower limb since 15 days. What would be treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The case given here is acute eruptive lichen planus. In this case, systemic corticosteroid along with topical steroids are needed.

Option A: In chronic cases with few lesions only topical steroids are required.

Option B: Antihistamines are prescribed for symptomatic treatment.

Option D: Acitretin is used for extensive hypertrophic Lichen planus

Key Takeaway:

Eruptive Lichen Planus is managed with systemic & Topical steroids both.

questions.text: A 15 year old male patient presented with pruritic, polygonal papules over the volar aspect of forearms.In histopathology eosinophilic hyaline ovoid bodies in lower epidermis and dermis were found. These structure are seen in all conditions given below except
questions.solution:
Clinical case given in the question is Lichen Planus.

Degenerated dead keratinocytes seen as eosinophilic hyaline ovoid bodies in lower epidermis and dermis known as Colloid body, Civatte body or cytoid body. Seen in Lichen Planus, Lupus erythematosus, Erythema multiforme, GVHD. ( Option A, B & C )

Colloid Body isn't seen in Psoriasis ( Option D )

Key Takeaway:

Colloid Bodies is seen in:

  • Lichen Planus
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Erythema Multiforme
  • GVHD

questions.text: A child presented with asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and on the shaft of penis, lesions on the forearm are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lichen nitidus is a chronic disease with tiny, shiny, pin point papules in children.

The lesions are asymptomatic, present over penis, forearm, extensors. Histopathology shows classical "clutching the ball" appearance. Papillae are elongated and curved downwards and holds a collection of dermal lymphocytes and histiocytes within it.


Option B: Lichen planus presents with pruritic, polygonal, purple papules.

Option C: Scrofuloderma is cutaneous tuberculosis

Option D: Scabies is an itchy condition caused by infestation of mites.

Key Takeaway:

Lichen Nitidus

  • Tiny, Shiny Pinpoint Papules on penis
  • Clutching ball Appearance
  • Asymptomatic Condition

questions.text: A 12-year old male presented with asymptomatic erythematous scaly lesions over back. There was a history of sore throat. There were collarette scales in erythematous lesions. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting, which resolves in about 6 - 10 weeks. It is characterized by a large circular or oval "herald patch", usually found on the chest, abdomen, or back.

The herald patch is followed some time later, typically two weeks or so, by the development of smaller scaly oval red patches, resembling a Christmas tree, distributed mainly on the chest and back.

Collarette scale is a characteristic sign in pityriasis rosea. With the edge peripherally attached and lifted up near the center of the lesion.

Option B:

Pityriasis rubra pilaris Scaly (Pityriasis), Pink to orange (Rubra), Follicular papules (pilaris), Grouped papules frequently coalesce to form large plaques, typically with distinct islands of normal skin and islands of normal skin are often studded with erythematous follicular scaly papules. Palm and sole are commonly involved with orange red waxy keratoderma.

Option C:

Pityriasis versicolor is a superficial fungal infection. There are hypo or hyperpigmented mildly scaly macules over neck,upper chest, upper back.

Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur

On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'spaghetti and meatball appearance'

On wood's lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Option D:

Guttate psoriasis is a variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults.

Manifests as numerous, small, scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as "drop-like" and typically manifest as 2 to 6 mm papules.

Key Takeaway:

Pityriasis rosea:

  • Characteristic Herald Patch
  • Christmas Tree Distribution of Scaly oval Red Patches on Chest & Back.
  • Collararet Scales

questions.text: A 50-year old male patient presented with follicular keratotic papules with islands of sparing, orange red plaques and keratoderma sandals. Which would be most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Orange-red keratotic follicular papules


Striking symmetric islands of sparing on the flanks. Follicular papules are present at the periphery of the diffuse erythema

Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) is an inflammatory papulosquamous disorder. There are well-demarcated plaques of various sizes with characteristic reddish-orange hue, which may have varying degrees of the scale. More generalized subtypes often demonstrate intervening areas of unaffected skin, known as "islands of sparing", which is a signature characteristic of PRP.

Option A: Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting, which resolves in about 6 10 weeks. It is characterized by a large circular or oval "herald patch", usually found on the chest, abdomen, or back.

The herald patch is followed some time later, typically two weeks or so, by the development of smaller scaly oval red patches, resembling a Christmas tree, distributed mainly on the chest and back.

Collarette scale is a characteristic sign in pityriasis rosea. With the edge peripherally attached and lifted up near the center of the lesion.

Option B: Pityriasis lichenoid chronica is Inflammatory rash characterized by diffuse red-brown papules in various stages with a mica-like scale on more established lesions. The papules may progress to form vesicles, pustules, and ulcers, and these lesions can be associated with pruritus or a burning sensation.

Option D: Pityriasis sicca is a common scalp condition referred to as dandruff.

Key Takeaway:

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris:

  • inflammatory papulosquamous disorder.
  • follicular keratotic papules with islands of sparing
  • orange red plaques and keratoderma sandals.
